title-group.article-title: Node-Failure Technique-Based Representative Unit-Cell Lifetime-Dependent Ductile Damage Model Between Elastoviscoplastic Matrix and Rigid Fiber

article-meta.aff: 1LASP, Department of Mechanical Engineering, USTO, BP 1055 El Menaour, Oran, Algeria
2LMPM, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Sidi Bel Abbes, Algeria
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, College of Engineering, King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s), 2011. Reprints and permissions: www.sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Numerical fracture mechanics analysis of the composite material presents many difficulties both for complexity of structure and various behaviors of its components. In recent years, there is an increasing trend of study about the initial crack location in internal microstructure of these materials. Numerical iterative computation procedure with the full mesh of composite structure, taking into account the elastoviscoplastic behavior and the failure criterion based on a locally accumulated damage to identify the path of the crack propagation, requires an important execution time, consequently an expensive cost. The aim of this article is the presentation of an original technique expressed as node-failure-based method developed in order to determine the initiation and progressive failure path using a nonlinear damage evolution law. In order to avoid the disadvantage of the full mesh, a representative unit-cell is adopted with adequate periodic boundary conditions to predict debonding initiation at fiber/matrix interface. The analysis shows finite element method–based representative unit-cell can reduce the computing power consumption and node-failure-based method act as a viable tool for prediction fracture pattern, while the well-known element-failure-based method, which requires more refined mesh of constant strain triangle elements is less accurate.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Generally, a material composite is assumed as a spatially periodic microstructure, whereas its microstructural characteristics can easily be simulated by representative unit-cells (RUC) with adequate periodic symmetry or antisymmetry boundary conditions. The mechanical behavior of heterogeneous composite materials is defined to characterize the nonlinear strain rate in order to determine the strain concentration level of a fiber-reinforced matrix interface. The mechanical model implemented to describe these processes considers for that the reinforcement component has elastic behavior and the matrix exhibits elastoviscoplastic behavior. In the present work, bidimensional (2D) unit-cell finite element (FE) model is developed for composite materials with cylindrical reinforcements in order to analyze the magnitude of strain concentrations that result from the various loading and their effects on decohesion between matrix and fiber.

Numerical methods have developed into useful tools to predict the mechanical behavior of materials for a wide range of constitutive equations, but real heterogeneous materials, in which the length scale difference between the macrostructure and the individual microstructural components can be several orders of magnitude, require an enormous amount of computer memory and computational time, and can therefore be practically infeasible. In general, the FE method is used for this purpose (Owen and Hinton, 1980; Crisfield, 1997; Simo and Hughes, 1998). Another way to model the deformation behavior of heterogeneous solids at the macro level is the use of a so called multilevel FE method where, on the different appropriate scales, simultaneous numerical calculations are performed (Ghosh et al., 1996; Miehe et al., 1998; Smit et al., 1998; Feyel and Chaboche, 2000; Kouznetsova et al., 2001). The most important benefit of the multilevel method appears to be the readily available information of the evolution of the microstructure during loading of the macroscopic structure and, therefore, the results of this method are quite accurate. Nevertheless, this approach poses severe limitations on practical applications with complex microstructures as well as complex macrostructures, as also this method is computationally expensive. This fact has also been pointed out by the users of the method (Lee and Ghosh, 1999).

In this article, the set of 2D RUC model by means of the node-failure-based method (NFM) simulation has been shown to be useful in investigating the crack initiation and propagation using a nonlinear damage evolution law. This choice was able to be conducted in a relatively short amount of time.

sec.title: DAMAGE MECHANISMS
sec.p: The importance of the fiber/matrix interface in determining damage tolerance has long been recognized (Thouless et al., 1989). Many compositematerials fail only after the accumulation of significant damage. This damage can be defined as the more or less gradual development of micro defects such as matrix or fiber cracks that eventually lead to final fracture (Ladeveze et al., 1994). This class of materials exhibits large nonlinear strains during tensile loading. The plastic strain is thought to be a consequence of matrix cracking and interfacial debonding or sliding. A weakly bonded interface, usually exhibits the risk of a catastrophic failure.

In metallic materials, the toughness enhancement is a result of their ability to absorb energy by plastic deformation. When matrix cracks run into fibers, cracks are deflected along the interface. Interfacial debonding is induced rather than fiber failure provided that the interface is relatively weak (Hutchinson and Jensen, 1990). Thus, the matrix will crack first under loading and the fibers are able to sustain the additional load when the matrix fails (Aveston et al., 1971). Finally, the damage evolution can be studied in axial and transverse directions. Continuous fiber-reinforced composites generally have superior mechanical properties along the fiber axial direction, and the design process normally attempts to take advantage of the relatively high stiffness and strength in the fiber direction. However, the rate-dependent kinetic behavior of material deformation with damage, which is typical for viscous materials, is highly relevant to the material response, when loading a sample orthogonally to the fiber direction. Specifically, transverse properties often become the limiting factors in the component’s performance.

sec.title: FRACTURE MODELING
sec.p: The debonding of the interface in composite materials can be characterized using two main approaches, either using a fracture mechanics or a decohesion zone approach. In either of these methods, the interface toughness is an important parameter in the analysis. This study, through force or displacement loading, investigates the interface fracture or decohesion characteristics of the composite.

In the global approach, nonlinear fracture mechanics only must be applied if a crack or defect is already present. Then, it cannot be successfully applied to predict ductile fracture. In contrast with these assumptions, local approach can predict both fracture initiation since no defect is required to evaluate the fracture criterion.

The methodology requires the iteration of two successive steps. The first one leads to locate the node-failure initiation, while the second one releases thefully damaged node to create and predict the failure path. Then, a fracture indicator D is introduced governing initiation of a crack as a measure for damage locally accumulated in the material, which is in generally form expressed as:

The local criteria for ductile fracture are generally based on an effective strain path integral (McClintock, 1968; Oyane et al., 1969, 1980; Rice and Tracey, 1969; Cockcroft and Latham, 1986). The quantitative damage criteria in the aluminum (Al)/silicon carbide (SiC) composites have been analyzed, tested, and verified in many works. The SiC fiber in Al matrix become damaged and fail, if the critical maximum principal stress exceeds a critical level (Hu et al., 1998; Derrien et al., 1999). In so doing, a number of different criteria of local failure are developed by (Rice and Tracey, 1969) including the critical equivalent plastic strain, triaxiality factor, and the damage indicator, based on the model of a spherical void growth in a plastic material in a general remote stress field with high stress triaxiality.

The damage parameter considered by (Wulf, 1995) is determined by integrating the incremental damage indicator, which is defined as an increment of the plastic strain divided by the reference failure strain.

In this study, a nonlinear damage evolution law has been used (see Figure 1) depending on accumulated viscoplastic strain, which reads: Figure 1.
Nonlinear damage evolution law.

sec.title: PERZYNA’S CONSTITUTIVE MODEL
sec.p: It is assumed that all the reinforcement fibers have the same dimensions and orientation and are uniformly distributed. The matrix and fiber materials are isotropic in stiffness. A perfect bonding between the Al matrix and the SiC reinforcement is assumed. The behavior of the reinforcement is considered to be elastic and the matrix to exhibit an elastic–viscoplastic constitutive behavior.

The mechanical behavior of both the fiber and the matrix material in the RUC is assumed to be described by elastic model and Perzyna’s viscoplastic model, respectively. The total strain εij is separated into elastic ɛij e and viscoplastic ɛij vp components (Zienkiewicz and Cormeau, 1974):

The onset of the viscoplastic behavior depends on a scalar yield condition F(σ,κ), where κis a history parameter. Von Mises yield criterion is chosen, suggesting that yielding occurs when the second deviatoric stress invariant J2 reached a critical value, or: (3)F(σ,κ)=3(J2)12-ς(κ) in one hand, yield criterion may be further written as: (4)σ¯=3(J2)12=32σij dσij d and, in an other hand, the function ς(κ) defines the current yield stress assumed linear in κ: (5) where σY is the initial yield stress and h is the hardening modulus.
Adopting the equivalent strain measure κ as the local effective viscoplastic strain ɛ¯p which is given by:
where γ a fluidity parameter, the vector aij is termed the flow vector and Φ(F) an overstress function. The amount of the viscoplastic strain rate is equal to the scalar value λ·=γΦ(F).
A power law is chosen for the overstress function (Perzyna, 1966, 1971):
with N the rate-sensitivity parameter.

sec.title: A NUMERICAL PROCEDURE DESCRIPTION
sec.p: Several works treated the debonding phenomenon at the interface fiber/matrix as a model (Lissenden and Herakovich, 1999) with elastic–viscoplastic matrix and nonlinear interfacial traction–displacement relations for the fiber/matrix interface, which shows that debonding significantly influences the transverse tensile and axial shear responses.

A series of criteria based on cohesive zone models are proposed by (Li and Gosh, 2007) for assessing the direction of damage development with an extended Voronoi cell FE model for modeling the initiation and propagation of interfacial debonding and matrix cracking in fiber-reinforced composite materials.

Also, a numerical study (Mishnaevsky and Brondsted, 2008) presents the effect of matrix failure and the interface strength including a cracked fiber. Anumerical investigation (Correa et al., 2008) assumed that the damage starts at the interfacial zone as small debonds originated by shear stresses at the position where their maximum values are reached.

A numerical methodology is presented allowing to determine the global stress and strain fields in the component taking into account the local stresses redistribution (at the scale of heterogeneities). This methodology is applied on Al components reinforced with long SiC fibers. The dissipative phenomena inside the structure are directly linked to the matrix viscoplasticity and the interface debond.

The elastoviscoplastic parameters of the constitutive equations of the matrix are deduced from experimental tests and the fibers are supposed to remain elastic. For that purpose, a numerical procedure was developed to determine the stress and strain concentration tensors in a RUC state.

The FE analysis of the component is performed in the following way. Starting from the macroscopic strain field on each integration point, determined with the equilibrium equation, the local strain field in a corresponding cell is established. Then, the local stress field and the interface debond are computed with their respective constitutive equations. This procedure on theunit-cell determines the macroscopic stress and plastic strain fields, which take into account a local damage governed by a fracture nonlinear law. Infact, during the FE analysis of the component, the stress field on each integration point is the result of a local FE analysis performed on a unit-cell loaded with the strain field of this integration point. This numerical procedure is applied to simulate various bidimensional industrial structures composite.

sec.title: NUMERICAL IMPLEMENTATION
sec.p: A numerical implementation is adopted for viscoplastic strain:
where the strain increment Δɛn vp occurring in a time interval Δtn=tn+1-tn, using an implicit time-stepping scheme, is defined as:
where:
θ = 0 – Euler time integration scheme;
θ = 1 – fully implicit scheme; and
θ = ½ – implicit trapezoidal scheme (Crank-Nicolson rule).
The time step is controlled by a factor τ, which limits the maximum effective viscoplastic strain increment:

sec.title: FE MODEL
sec.p:
In the case of transversely loaded unidirectional composites, the microstructure is characterized by a regular arrangement of fibers in Al matrix, Figure 2(a). Since a detailed geometrical model of this microstructure would lead to excessive computing time, especially in the case of time-dependent behavior, the topography is usually simplified by assuming a more regular stacking of the fibers from which a repeating unit needs to be modeled as aRUC, in order to decrease the number of elements and consequently a simulation time. A FE program was performed, based on a pre-processor as a mesh generator and applied boundary conditions, a solver with elastoviscoplatic constitutive model with iterative steps of time and loading, and a postprocessor to visualize all results. The mesh represents a fiber-volume fraction of 33% and consists of 1972 generalized plane strain eight-nodes isoparametric quadrilateral elements, Figure 2(b). A sufficient refining mesh was adopted especially in the fiber/matrix interface. The corresponding boundary conditions for the RUC are indicated in Figure 2(c). In the simulations, a displacement loading is applied. Figure 2.
(a) Periodic square array of fibers, (b) Representation of the representative unit-cell (RUC), and (c) Mesh and boundary conditions.

sec.title: Nodal Smoothing Technique
sec.p:
In the displacement method, the stress and strain fields are discontinuous between elements because of the type of the displacement functions. A typical stress distribution is shown in Figure 3. The integration Gauss points are the best sampling points in the integrated isoparametric elements. To evaluate the nodal values, local smoothing technique, Figure 4, is applied using a simply bilinear extrapolation of the 2 × 2 Gaussian integration point stress, strain, and damage values. Thus, in order to evaluate these fields in any space position, it is necessary to follow three steps: Figure 3.
Unsmoothed stress distributions. Figure 4.
Bidimensional (2D)-parabolic isoparametric element.

list-item.p: First, the smoothed corner node values are obtained from the Gaussian point values using Equation (12).
Then, evaluate the common nodal averaged value from all elements contributions containing this node.

Finally, the mid-side node values are interpolated by averaging the values at the nodes associated with the side in question, since the distribution of the smoothed stresses is linear along the sides of the elements.

sec.p: All smoothed values are averaged to obtain unique values at nodal points.
Where σ~1, σ~2, σ~3, and σ~4 are the smoothed corner values and σI, σII, σIII and σIV are the unsmoothed stresses at the points as defined in Figure 4.

sec.title: Failure Criterion: A Macro–Micro Approach
sec.p: With the geometrical assumptions and the choice of the constitutive behavior, it is easy to simulate the mechanical response of unidirectional composites in transverse loading. However, a failure criterion for the matrix material has to be defined. For the prediction of failure at a certain strain value, this criterion is based on the detection of the locally accumulated damage in the RUC during a simulated loading sequence.

In this study, a critical damage criterion was chosen, more specifically the critical value of a full degradation of material occurs, which is indicated bythe fracture indicator D = 1. Consequently, the fully damaged point represented by a node is released leading to describe a created crack in the matrix material. The reason of the anticipated micromechanical approach isthat to predict the crack location for studying it with the macroscopic fracture mechanic. With respect to the aim of this study being lifetime prediction of composite materials, this is especially the case, since relative small changes in the applied displacement loading lead to large changes in local plastic deformation rates, and thus strong variations in lifetime predictions. In the micromechanical simulations, based on a regular stacking pattern, the influence of imperfections is omitted and consequently, the strength and lifetime of the composite will be overestimated.

sec.title: Numerical Modeling of Surface Measurements in Transverse Tensile Tests
sec.p: The technique based on the strain invariant failure theory and the element-failure-based method (EFM; Tay et al., 2005) simulates the damage evolution in unit-cell analysis of the composite, which is realized by applying a set that the damaged element is zeroed. In this study, this well-known technique is modified in original idea by using NFM, taking into account the successive fully damaged nodes which are released to indicate the crack growth path. This choice is based on most accuracy plane strain isoparametric FE with smoothed values at nodes than constant strain element used in above technique, which needs more refining mesh, then more time computing.

As mentioned above, a prescribed displacement loading is used to determine the critical value of the damage indicator. For this purpose, a numerical simulation was performed and stopped at the threshold value corresponding to the unit value of the damage indicator (D = 1). The corresponding critical prescribed value of the displacement is 5 µm. The distributions of the equivalent von Mises and hydrostatic stresses, equivalent plastic strain, and damage indicator are shown in Figure 5(a)–(d). Figure 5.
(a) Distribution of von Mises stress, (b) Distribution of hydrostatic stress, (c) Distribution of plastic strain, and (d) Damage indicator for the first damaged node.

After releasing the fully damaged node in order to simulate the nodal force relaxation in the fiber/matrix interface, the next step of program computation gives these distributions in Figure 6(a) and (b). Figure 6.
(a) Crack path between the first released fully damaged node and the next damaged node and (b) View of effective plastic strain reaching the critical value.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This method allows to predict the failure in the viscoplastic material under loading conditions without existing cracks. The applied nonlinear damage law gives the unit value when the plastic strain reaches the critical value which is the material property (Correa et al., 2008; Mishnaevsky and Brondsted, 2008). After treating the fully geometrical representative unit-cell, only the first anticlockwise quadrant is considered.

Because of the accumulated plastic strain that occurs during the loading, the damage law indicates the first fully damaged node location (D = 1) which permits to create a crack, since the node in question becomes released. Then, a nodal force relaxation method is adopted and the next computation steps can easily determine the next fully damaged nodes one by one in order to follow the path of crack propagation.

Especially, in the time history stresses distributions for the first fully damaged node, the hydrostatic stress has not a high influence on the material damage face to the von Mises stress, which is clearly the greatest one (see Figure 7). Figure 7.
Normalized von Mises and hydrostatic stresses vs effective plastic strain for the first fully damaged node.

The overestimation of the first node location is at θ = 34° on the interface, while the second one is at θ = 28° on the interface (see Figure 8). All the calculated fully damaged nodes are located on the fiber/matrix interface, which permits to conclude that a debonding phenomenon is occurring between fiber and matrix, while the unit-cell is under loading. Figure 8.
Effective plastic strain and damage along the first anticlockwise quadrant.
The NFM compared to EFM using removal damaged triangular element provides some advantages:

list-item.p: It is well-known that eight-nodes isoparametric elements give most accuracy results than constant strain triangle elements (CST).

While solving step-by-step, it is easier to release a damaged node creating a crack than to remove a triangular element by cancelling its Young modulus, thus disturbing the global stiffness of the structure.
Technique NFM requires a less-refined mesh than EFM approach.

sec.p: Comparisons of these simulations with reference results validate the effectiveness of this new technique. The capability of predicting initiation and growth failure path without existing cracks in composites is of great importance to the design and evaluation of structure.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p:
This article shows that this FE program is a viable tool for modeling not only a fracture mechanic but also prediction fracture pattern with NFM. The crack-propagation technique based on the path of the fully degradation of the material presented in this article, taken together, the micro and macro approaches, decreases highly the computation time compared to the global heterogeneous structure analysis because the RUC requires a less number of elements envisaged in full-mesh structure on the one hand. On the other hand, it is well known that the plane strain isoparametric element gives best accuracy results than the CST to compute the stress and strain fields. It was seen that the failure occurs at the interface fiber/matrix highlighting the debonding phenomenon. Table 1.
Properties of materials.
